results.title: Beau Geste
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation, Barry Letts and Douglas Camfield
results.brief_description: From the novel by P.C. Wren, “Beau Geste” is the adventures of three aristocratic British brothers who turn their backs on their privileged lives and join the French Foreign Legion. Drawn together by the ties of blood and loyalty, their courage and honour are tested in the harsh desert world. This is another excellent BBC adaptation and stars Benedict Taylor as Beau Geste, Anthony Calf as Digby and Johnathon Morris as John.

results.title: Beatrix Potter: artist, storyteller and countrywoman
results.brief_description: Based on the biography of the same name by Judy Taylor, this is the first documentary about the life of Beatrix Potter. Rich in rare photographic family portraits, archival images of her homes, farms and environment, her exquisite watercolours and famous illustrations, this is a complete biography. Narrated by Lynn Redgrave and written by Judy Taylor, the story of a remarkable and talented woman emerges. Best known as an English author and illustrator, primarily for her unique children’s books, her family origins were in Lancashire, where cotton mills and calico printing created the family wealth. She was born (28/7/1866) and raised in affluent isolation on the edge of central London, rural Kensington, in late Victorian England. Not sent to school because she was considered sickly and educated by a series of governesses until the birth of a sibling, she developed an observance and love of nature at a very early age, coupled with a natural talent for drawing. Her nursery floor was inhabited by all sorts of creatures brought home to London from summer holidays in Scotland. She cared for, observed and loved them as friends and spent much time drawing them. Her first book, “The Tale of Peter Rabbit”, was based on an illustrated letter about her pet rabbit, sent to her governess’s son. Her lawyer father’s influence was strong. A talented amateur photographer who did preparatory studies for the painter Millet, he admired and avidly collected original works of illustrators of the day. She became financially independent in her 20’s through her children’s books and remained the dutiful Victorian daughter into her 40’s, caring for her demanding parents in London but escaping for intervals to her sheep farm in the Lake District. Here she met her husband, virtually stopped publishing and became a successful sheep farmer and environmentalist, holding and managing over 4000 acres, 17 farms, at the time of her death in 1944. She left two legacies: her land and her books. Her land was left to the National Trust with the condition it was to be let and managed as it was in her lifetime, and that each fell or farm was to support a sheep flock of the pure Herdwick breed native to the district. Her books, where as artist and poet she was, “able to create that rare thing, books that bring grown-ups and children together in a shared delight” (editorial, New York Herald Tribune 1944), are now translated into a multitude of languages including Latin, Spanish, Polish and Japanese.

results.title: Beating the drum
results.creator_credit: Film Finance Corporation Australia, F-Reel Pty Ltd, Fiona Cochrane and Louise Hubbard
results.brief_description: Melbourne has proven to be a mecca of sorts for musicians, with virtually any style of music being performed in clubs and halls across the city at any one time. ‘Beating the drum’ showcases some of these extraordinary performers who have migrated to Australia- some retain their traditional style, others have blended it in collaboration with other musicians. Both methods reflect the bigger issue of the cultural appropriation of music- whether there is such a thing, is there a right and wrong way to do it, how does Aboriginal music fit into this notion, and what we mean by world music? Musicians, academics, broadcasters and World Music aficionados take up this discussion through words and music. Musicians include: Xylouris Ensemble, Kavisha Mazzella and La Voce Della Luna, George Telek, Rembetika Compania, Terrasphere, Tom E. Lewis, Inka Marka, Taksim, Thula Sana, Adzohu, Fronteras, Vladimir Kocibelli, Petrunka, Tsicaderis Ensemble and Ta’Esh Fa’Esh.

results.title: Beating the clock - at work: the limits of human performance
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development, Steve Skok and Jeff Spencer
results.brief_description: Looks at ways in which people try to enhance their performance levels in relation to real or perceived times and the ensuing results.

results.title: Beating the clock - at sport: the limits of human performance
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development, Steve Skok and Jeff Spencer
results.brief_description: One of a series of programmes produced in conjunction with the Youth ANZAAS Science Festival. While looking at the differences in human performances at Olympic Games, the question is raised as to how one person can do so much better than another and why performance times have improved so much

results.title: Beating the bracken
results.creator_credit: New South Wales. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: Recommends methods of removing bracken from the rich dairy country in the New South Wales coastal belt. Explains that broken bracken is the first stage in the removal of the pest. Illustrates the use of specially designed three-bladed rollers on hilly country. On level pastures the simple square log roller with steel flanges, the mower, the rotary hoe, or other mechanical equipment are suggested.

results.title: Beating about the bush (A)
results.creator_credit: Titus Films, Nicholas Adler and Caroline Sherwood
results.brief_description: The film follows the tour of Djaambi, a half Aboriginal, half white, urban band from Melbourne, under the leadership of Richard Frankland as they travel to remote Aboriginal communities in outback Australia. It explores the cultural mix within the band and the culture shock all members of the band, particularly the Aboriginal members, experience as they meet another, very different side of their culture. Towards the end of the tour the various problems and cultural confusions become focused in a radical split between the white film makers and the more vocal Aboriginal band members. A disturbing look at good intentions gone wrong.

results.title: Beaten metalwork, seaming: making a child's mug
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic Metalwork”.
This film shows the making of a child’s mug right through from the sheet metal to the finished article and gives an opportunity for a number of craft operations to be observed; the design on paper, transference to metal sheet decoration, stages in forming the body of the mug, by bending, seaming, beating, and planishing. The base and the handle are seen being fashioned and joined to the body by brazing. Finally the cleaning up and polishing are shown.

results.title: Beat the heat: energy efficient housing
results.creator_credit: Telefeatures, South Australian Film Corporation, Nicholas Cockram and Mario Andreacchio
results.brief_description: A film designed to show the general public how, by the use of insulation, correct orientation of a house, placement of windows, etc., the unpleasant effects of intensive summer heat can be alleviated.

results.title: Beat the devil (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: Romulus Films, Santana, Jack Clayton and John Huston
results.brief_description: The story of a motley group of swindlers travelling on an Africa-bound tramp steamer. The plot unfolds to reveal a web of double crossing and deception as each attempts to get their hands on a fortune in uranium deposits. Starring Gina Lollobrigida and Humphrey Bogart. Written by Truman Capote and John Huston from a novel by James Helvick. This version includes an introduction by Tony Curtis and a bonus clip of the original theatrical trailer for Humphrey Bogart’s ‘The Big sleep’.
